item.title: Creating A Vector Graphics Version Of The Arrecibo Message
item.description: I recently remembered the very cool Arrecibo message and I discovered the Wikipedia article on it is truly fantastic. After reading about the meaning of all its parts of the message, I decided I wanted a printed copy for my home. In this post I describe how I generated the print-ready image file. Here is the message: Arrecibo Message. Image from Wikipedia by Arne Nordmann (norro), CC BY-SA 3.0,

item.title: Creating This Blog Part 2
item.description: This is a follow-up to a previous post describing how I set up this blog. Here I describe a couple of extra pieces of the setup including more elaborate multilingual support, the creation of a multilingual footer for all posts, and the about page. Multilingual Text “Snippets” Using i18n Hugo comes built in with with a very nice and simple way to specify fixed texts that should change according to the language.

item.title: Translating the Illustrative Mathematics K-8 Educational Resources
item.description: I was recently invited to participate in a webinar as the lead Spanish translator of the Illustrative Mathematics K-8 Curriculum (see here). The main point they wanted me to discuss was what was our process translating the resources, and why a simple word-for-word translation like that could be put into Google insufficient. As a preparation for this webinar, I decided to write this blog entry describing detailed answers to this prompt.

item.title: Covid-19 Delta Variant % Share of Cases Grew Logistically
item.description: Today, as part of my work, I stumbled upon the surprising fact that in many countries the % share of Covid-19 cases that were Delta variant grew almost perfectly logistically from 0% to 100% during 2021. The graph below, which started all of this, should come up if one follows this Our World In Data link. Image downloaded from Our World in Data, open access under the Creative Commons BY license.

item.title: Creating this Blog: Hugo, making the Hyde theme multilingual, and adding Latex support
item.description: This blog does not live in a commercial platform for bloggers. It is what is technically called a “static site”, meaning it is just a collection of html files that are linked between each other and some other formatting files (css, for example). As such, it can be hosted anywhere and is not tied to any particular platform. Moreover, it was created with a fantastic open source tool caled Hugo. In this blog entry I explain how I set it up.
